docs.lead_paragraph: UNLIKE the world's fanciest hotels and restaurants, car dealerships are hardly the kinds of places people think of as rating five stars, where how people are treated matters as much as what they've come to buy. But DaimlerChrysler is spending big bucks -- more than $30 million -- on a new advertising campaign by Bozell Worldwide, a unit of Bozell Inc., to try to change that perception, at least for its 4,500 dealers nationwide. More important, the ad campaign reflects the company's response to the changing environment for car dealers, who have come under pressure in recent years as auto superstores like Car Max have come on the scene, and again as more people try to buy cars on the Internet to avoid repeating bad experiences in car dealerships.

headline.main: DaimlerChrysler is waving carrots and sticks to try to get dealers to treat customers right.

docs.abstract: DaimlerChrysler is spending more than $30 million on new advertising campaign by Bozell Worldwide to try to change perception of car dealerships; campaign reflects company's response to changing environment for car dealers, who have come under pressure in recent years as auto superstores like Car Max have come on scene, and again as more people try to buy cars on Internet to avoid repeating bad experiences in car dealerships; DaimlerChrysler will try to harness its vast purchasing power to offer dealerships that treat customers right the chance to save money by buying goods and services through auto company (Advertising column) (M)
docs.snippet: UNLIKE the world's fanciest hotels and restaurants, car dealerships are hardly the kinds of places people think of as rating five stars, where how people are treated matters as much as what they've come to buy.    But DaimlerChrysler is spending big...

docs.lead_paragraph: For years, Medicare officials have railed against fraud by doctors and hospitals. But now Federal investigators have traced much of the problem to people in the companies that pay Medicare claims for the Government -- the very people who are supposed to be policing fraud in the giant health insurance program for the elderly. In the last two years, at least 4 of the 44 companies that run Medicare's day-to-day financial operations, in California, Colorado, Illinois and New Mexico, have pleaded guilty to criminal charges in schemes to defraud the Government. Executives at two other Medicare contractors, in New York and Pennsylvania, have been found guilty of similar charges.

headline.main: FRAUD IN MEDICARE INCREASINGLY TIED TO CLAIMS PAYERS

docs.abstract: General Accounting Office report finds pattern of 'improprieties' among contractors that pay Medicare claims for Government, the very companies that are suppposed to be be policing Medicare fraud; investigation finds that contractors filed false claims, improperly destroyed thousands of claims to reduce backlog, and shut down telephone systems when inundated with customers' calls; eight companies have paid more than $275 million in fines to settle charges of defrauding Government; Department of Health and Human Services is investigating 19 others; chart shows how claims are processed (M)
docs.snippet: For years, Medicare officials have railed against fraud by doctors and hospitals. But now Federal investigators have traced much of the problem to people in the companies that pay Medicare claims for the Government -- the very people who are supposed...

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 First Peacekeepers Arrive in East Timor The first units of an international peacekeeping force landed in East Timor to quell a campaign of terror unleashed when residents voted for independence from Indonesia three weeks ago. In advance of the deployment, the mission's commander, Maj. Gen. Peter Cosgrove of Australia, visited Dili, the capital, to coordinate the effort. A1 Tokyo and Seoul Draw Closer The Governments of South Korea and Japan are drawing dramatically closer, bringing a new spirit of respect and reconciliation to one of Asia's most bitter relationships. Officials say South Korea and Japan have been driven together by a variety of factors, including a common threat from North Korea. A1

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN Antony L. Dugdale, a graduate student, arrived at Yale University in 1993 to pursue a Ph.D., he was shocked. Graduate students who taught undergraduates as teaching assistants had formed a labor union and were trying to get Yale to recognize it as a collective bargaining agent. ''I thought it was inappropriate and silly,'' he recalled. ''This was a university, after all, not a factory.''

headline.main: Graduate Students Strive for Union at Yale

docs.abstract: Article on efforts by Yale University graduate students to force university to recognize their union, Graduate Employees and Students Organization, as collective bargaining agent; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: WHEN three sergeants retired recently from the Nassau County Police Department, they began collecting generous annual pensions worth at least half the top salary they earned on the job. But first they collected something more: Lump-sum payments in a combined total of nearly $700,000 for unused sick days, vacation days, personal days and other items, all according to contract and typical of amounts the county will be obliged to pay other superior officers as they retire. As Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta seeks support in Mineola and on Wall Street for a proposed Year 2000 budget that comes at a time when the county faces a deficit of $240 million, soaring lump-sum payments to retiring county officers of all ranks are destabilizing county finances already strained by rising police costs.

headline.main: Police Contract: The Hole in Nassau's Bucket

docs.abstract: Article on soaring lump-sum payments for unused sick days, vacation days, personal days and other items to retiring Nassau County, NY, police officers in light of projected $240 million budget deficit; payouts could run into tens of millions of dollars over next several years; predictions are that challenges to police compensation could strengthen if there is economic downturn (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, Representative George E. Brown Jr., an old-line liberal Democrat first elected to Congress in 1962, was a top target for Republicans eager to win a seat in California's sprawling ''Inland Empire'' of semi-desert suburbs and commuter communities. And more than once, Mr. Brown came close to losing, so when the Congressman died in July at 79 after complications from heart surgery, a close race to succeed him seemed all but inevitable. But for the moment, that close race is between two Democrats vying for their party's nomination in a special election on Sept. 21. And the contest, the first Congressional election of the 2000 cycle, says much about the changing demographics of a district where the first McDonald's drive-in opened in the years after World War II. Once a solid blue-collar steel-making center on the path of Route 66, the area became a beachhead of Reagan Republicanism, and in recent years there has been a steady rise in the influence of Hispanic voters, who are expected to exert growing power in California's politics in the coming years.

headline.main: Close Contest for House Seat From California

docs.abstract: Marta Macias Brown, widow of Rep George E Brown Jr, and State Sen Joe Baca lead in race for Democratic nomination for Brown's Congressional seat from California; both are Hispanic in district where newly registered Hispanic voters have swelled Democratic ranks; eight other candidates run in open primary, with top finisher from each party advancing to general election if none gets majority; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN her prime, Mary Russo of the Fort Hamilton section of Brooklyn did not have enough hours in the day. Ever since her husband left back in the 1940's when their three children were young, she supported the family alone, managing a Staten Island pizzeria and selling vacuum cleaners door to door. ''I loved selling those Filter Queen vacuums with all the attachments,'' she said. ''I was a good seller. I won the busy bee worker pin one month.''
docs.abstract: Article on relationships between elderly New York City residents who can no longer care for themselves and their home attendants; close bond formed between Italian woman, Mary Russo, 77, and her full-time caretaker, Trinidadian Joan Arthur, who spends 10 hours a day, 5 days a week with Mary, described; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Brera Capital Partners, a New York-based investment company, agreed to pay $165 million to acquire 91 percent of the GAB Robins insurance-services unit from SGS Holding A.G., a Swiss goods-inspection company that runs customs services for about 30 nations. The Geneva-based SGS expects proceeds of $143 million after tax, fees and the repayment of debt. Depressed trade volumes in emerging markets in Latin America and Africa are keeping the pressure on SGS to continue its plan to cut as many as 3,500 jobs and sell off or shake up struggling divisions after it slumped to a loss last year. Last week, it sold its health-care and biosciences-services units. SGS said it would keep Intermodal Transportation Services, a United States-based unit of GAB Robins with expected 1999 revenue of $75 million.

headline.main: BRERA CAPITAL PARTNERS TO ACQUIRE INSURANCE UNIT

docs.abstract: Brera Capital Partners agrees to pay $165 million to acquire 91 percent of GAB Robins insurance-services unit from SGS Holding AG (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The evacuations, disaster declarations and emergency proclamations that are accompanying Hurricane Floyd along the Atlantic coast are a small taste of worse to come, say coastal scientists and policy makers worried about rising sea levels, more intense storms and a ballooning coastal population. Weather forecasters at the National Hurricane Center and elsewhere have gotten better and better at predicting when and where storms will strike, helping officials to move residents and tourists out of harm's way in time. But population growth along the coast -- fueled in part, some experts say, by government policies encouraging development -- is more than outpacing them. Within a few years, some demographers predict, most Americans will live in coastal counties.

headline.main: Growth and Government Collude in Creating a Hazard

docs.abstract: Coastal scientists and policy makers say evacuations, disaster declarations and emergency proclamations accompanying Hurricane Floyd are a small taste of worse to come as sea levels continue to rise, storms intensify and more and more people live in vulnerable coastal areas; many warn that people will continue to build on the beach even if Federal agenices halted disaster assistance, insurance programs, infrastructure support and other spending that encourages it; say getting people off the coast safely in event of a storm is turning into a logistical nightmare (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: House Republican leaders, who directed junior members of the party to draft a bill defining patients' rights just five weeks ago, criticized the results of that effort today, saying the bill could expose health maintenance organizations to costly lawsuits. If House Republicans have any strategy for dealing with the volatile issue of patients' rights, it was not evident when they finished an hourlong meeting today in the office of Speaker J. Dennis Hastert.

headline.main: G.O.P. Cool On Its Plan For H.M.O.'s

docs.abstract: House Republican leaders score patients' rights bill drafted by Reps Tom Coburn and John Shadegg, holding bill could expose health maintenance organizations to costly suits; Coburn holds any bill must have liability as mechanism to hold health plans accountable (M)
